title: Before 27 June 2020, will the weekly average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances in the U.S. fall below 3.00%?
preds: Weekly update: "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) remained unchanged at 3.30 percent." https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/june/mortgage-applications-decrease-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey-x270845
Initial forecast. Only 4 days left in forecast.  Current crowd forecast is zero. Current interest rate is 3.3% (17 June)
Rates ticked higher. Since it is a weekly average, now no mathematical chance.

While mortgage rates are typically in lock-step with the 10-yr Treasury, there is substantial separation between the two right now. We've previously seen a 0.22 point drop week over week, and right now we would only need to see a 0.14 point drop to get below 3%. The harsh reality is that most investors are jittery enough, as seen by the current stock market, to jolt the mortgage market rate that much lower, even with an 8% delinquency rate.
July is quite possible, I don't think June.  With demand holding steady, and very slightly improved jobs reports, I don't see it this week.

https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/june/mortgage-applications-increase-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey-x264417 Latest nos for 30 Y fixed rate mortgages with confirming loan balances came in at 3.30% (down from 3.38%) for the week ending June 12th. While this is one of the lowest surveyed rates historically, I do not see a reason why it should fall below 3.00% in the next 2 weeks. Moving to a 0% probability for Yes.
I actually think it's between 0% and 1% based on requiring >3SDs deviation from trend.
Currently 3.13% -- a drop of .14 would be a decline of at least 4% in just 10 days.  Mortgage rates don't move that fast barring some extraordinary Fed action.

Dropped to 3.13 today. Market still volatile. Fed has not increased rate.  At the same point, other indicators are looking up which could cause banks to remain above.  I am putting it at too close to call now 50/50.
Mortgage rates are historically low and will not fall below 3% due to the risks involved with the housing market.

The latest survey, out today, says "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) decreased to 3.30 percent from 3.38 percent, the lowest level in survey history, ..."  This was a pretty big move, but it's too little, too late to reach the 3% target. It's only anecdotal evidence, but I know someone who is buying a house.  Lenders are not being responsive to their inquiries because they are slammed with more applications than they can process.  In such an environment why would they lower rates that are already at historical lows? When this question was first posed I said "heck yes, they'll have to lower rates to stimulate the economy."  The lesson for me is that when my first reaction to a question is certainty I need to take a breath, then dig deeper before forming an opinion.  I should have remembered the lessons from the book, "Thinking Fast and Slow" by Daniel Kahneman.  It's an excellent read for forecasters, IMHO. https://www.amazon.com/Thinking-Kahneman-Impression-published-Doubleday/dp/B009JIF284/

Surprise decrease in this week's report: "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) decreased to 3.30 percent from 3.38 percent, the lowest level in survey history." https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/june/mortgage-applications-increase-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey-x264417 Still, it's extremely unlikely it'll fall below 3% in the next ten days.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-06-16/harvard-s-rogoff-negative-rates-should-be-on-the-table-for-fed-video Could drive 30 yrs market rate first down harshly, and then, counter-intuitively and unexpectedly, up, since negative rates are a clear as possible sign of an economy in a prolonged crisis, and could thereby affect long-term trustworthiness and  ratings in the USA as a debtor. Decline in attractiveness of US government benchmark bonds as an asset class, in credit ratings and credit quality, and the looming possibility of a credit default (be it of technical nature or for any minor reason) could be the result.
I guess the resolution lies within the time span, when benchmark rates could be driven down...
Rates are not falling at that rate.  With two weeks to go, maybe they 3% on the nose? https://www.bankrate.com/mortgages/rates/mortgage-rates-for-monday-june-15-2020/
I think I’m ready to call this one. There may be some volatility through month-end, but that should cause spreads to widen and (likely) put mortgage rates higher.
Trending down with 2 reporting weeks to go.
No, it is currently showing a slight upward trend.
2.97% on June 11 according to Mortgage News Daily
Banks won't drop them that low with the political, economic, and health instability

Latest weekly report out 2 days ago: "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) increased to 3.38 percent from 3.37 percent." https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/june/mortgage-applications-increase-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey Rates seem to have already hit a low.
Even with rates falling below 3% capacity does not exist in the origination process to sufficiently handle sufficient contracts to average down to sub 3% rates across all credit tiers.
I think it will settle at 3.0-3.25.
30 year rate will not fall that fast
June 10 survey says ... "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) increased to 3.38 percent from 3.37 percent, ..."

Cutting forecast in half with 3 weeks to go. Spreads are tightening, but overall yields are rising. Fed is slowly reducing weekly purchases. Waiting to go to zero given uncertain nature of early recovery.

Latest weekly report out yesterday: "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) decreased to 3.37 percent from 3.42 percent." https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/june/mortgage-applications-decrease-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey Still quite a ways to go for it to fall below 3%.

The weekly MBA survey out today says "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) decreased to 3.37 percent from 3.42 percent, ... ."

Mortgage rates at record low and jump in mortgage applications. To get below 3.00% would require 0.37% decrease which is highly unlikely. Over the past few weeks rates have barely moved and most signs are pointing in the direction of them staying the same or increasing with the recovery. Odds of something significant happening in the next 24 days that would change this is minimal. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/03/mortgage-demand-from-homebuyers-spikes-18percent.html

https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/may/mortgage-applications-increase-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey-x264194 Latest nos show an increase from 3.41 to 3.42 (week on week). Revising to a 3% chance for a fall below 3.00%
Seems unlikely due to a quick housing recovery. Rate rose 0.01 points [1]. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/27/mortgage-demand-from-homebuyers-shows-strong-and-quick-recovery.html
mba 30 year fixed was still 3.42 on May 24th.
I've spent enough time at 1, I'll go for the nice soft round number. My view has not changed, just my number.

Latest weekly report out today: "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) increased to 3.42 percent from 3.41 percent." https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/may/mortgage-applications-increase-in-latest-mba-weekly-survey-x264194 Rates seem to have already hit a low.

The weekly survey out today says:  "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) increased to 3.42 percent from 3.41 percent, with points remaining unchanged at 0.33 (including the origination fee) for 80 percent loan-to-value ratio (LTV) loans. The effective rate increased from last week." The crowd has been trending down on this one; the crowd is probably right.  I'll track the crowd.

I am pretty sure I got this one completely wrong, and my Brier score is going to take an enormous hit.  WHAT I GOT WRONG Initially, this problem seemed to be a slam dunk, a no brainer, based upon what I remembered from my days as double major in math/cs and economics.  It was a 100 percent yes. I failed to consider a number of factors and just used what I remembered.  In US economic history, we learned that during the depression deflation was about two to three percent per year, and interest rates followed deflation down to about slightly above .56 percent in 1934.  However, the banks refused to make loans and were accused of hoarding money.  The situation was somewhat similar to the 2007 Great Recession during which President George W. Bush repeated the accusation.   In school, I thought about it and concluded there were probably two reasons.     The more obvious reason for “hoarding money” was the greater risk of default during a recession.    The less obvious reason was that banks did not want to become locked into long term loans with low interest rates.  Banks borrow short term and lend long term.   The interest rates on passbook checking accounts are much lower the interest rates on a mortgage.  Of course,  banks paid no interest on checking accounts in 1930s.  This was the source of funds for mortgage lending. Interest rates rise as the recession ends and gross domestic product and inflation rise.  A bank that made long term mortgage loans during a deep recession or depression later on could end up paying out more in short term interest to depositors than it collected from borrowers.  This was exactly the situation in the early 1980s, when many savings and loans went bankrupt.    I am still fairly sure I was right. I expected this recession to follow the pattern of the 1930s.  That is, inflation would become negative very quickly and interest rates, including the MBA survey rate, would follow this deflation down.  After all, it took several years in the 1930s for the economy to fall as far as it did in just a few weeks this year.  I was wrong because I failed to consider several factors.  WHAT I SHOULD HAVE CONSIDERED The real question is what is the floor for the MBA survey rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances in the absolute worst case scenario, which is what we are experiencing today.  What is a 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances?   I did not even ask this question.  A 30-year fixed-rate mortgage with conforming loan balances is a mortgage on a single family dwelling that meets the requirements of Freddie Mac or Fanny Mae.  The main requirement is the loan amount must be less than $510k in most but not all areas. ($765k in certain high priced urban areas.)  The amounts change each year.  Banks prefer these loans because they are easier to package and sell and are insured. What are the Historical Baseline rates? I only have information for the MBA survey rate going back to January 2020.  The MBA sells its survey information going all the way back to the 1970s for $150, which I was not willing to pay just to answer this question.    The range for the MBA survey rate was 3.40% to 3.95, YTD; that is, from January 2, 2020 to May 21, 2020.  The mean was 3.63 percent, and the standard deviation was .1938 percent.  Therefore, the MBA survey rate has traded in a narrow range of .55 percent.  The MBA survey rate traded in an even narrower range in the last 60 days.  I used March 26, 2020 as the starting point.   I chose this date because the major effects of the coronavirus on the economy started about this time as evidenced by the jump in unemployment claims.  In this period, the MBA survey rate range narrowed to 3.40 to 3.49 percent.  The mean decreased to 3.44, and the standard deviation decreased to .0280 percent.     Therefore, the MBA survey rate has been fluctuating in a much more narrow range in the last 60 days-- after the effects of the coronavirus.  However,  the bottom of the YTD and 60 day ranges is the same at about 3.40-3.41 percent.  I was correct in that the MBA survey rate tracked the 30 year treasury rate.  The correlation between these two numbers YTD was  .9167.   That is, 91.67 percent of the movement in the MBA survey can be explained by movements in the 30 year treasury rate.  The range of the difference between the two rates was 1.53 to 2.26, and the standard deviation was .2504.   The minimum difference between the two rates YTD was 1.53 percent on January 9, 2020.  The greatest difference was 2.26 percent on April 23, 2020.   The lowest values for the MBA survey were 3.40 and the most recent number 3.41.  The MBA rate mean is 1.9276 percent above the 30  year treasury mean YTD.   Yet, the 30 year treasure rate is a lot more volatile.  The 30 year treasury rate range was 1.18 to 2.28 percent YTD.  The mean YTD was 1.6986 percent and the standard deviation was .4158 percent.  However, in the last 60 days the 30 year treasury rate range narrowed to 1.18 to 1.42 percent.  The mean decreased to 1.3011 and the standard deviation narrowed to .0793.  This rate does not seem to be limited by a “floor” as does the MBA survey rate. The correlation between these number has grown however.  The range of the difference between the MBA survey rate and the 30 year treasury rate increased from a YTD mean of 1.70  to 2.24 percent in the last 60 days.  Thus, they are moving apart, and this is important.  The divergence indicates that the MBA survey rate has not followed the 30 year treasury rate to its lowest levels.  The MBA survey has hit a floor in the 3.40 and 3.49 percent range while the 30 treasury fell much further and in the last 60 days bounced around between 1.18 and 1.42 percent Thus, YTD and in the last 60 days the floor of the MBA rate has been about 3.40 percent, which it hit as the 30 year treasury rate fell below about 1.40 -1.42 percent.  It did not matter how far the 30 year rate fell below 1.40 percent; how long it remained below 1.40 percent; or, what the 30 year rate range was below 1.40 percent.  The MBA survey rate stubbornly remained at or above 3.40 percent up to the most recent MBA survey.   What is the Comparison to Great Recession and Great Depression?  I wanted to look at the MBA survey rates during the great recession and great depression for comparison.  However, I was not going to pay the $150 to MBA purchase their historical data just to answer this question.   Fannie Mae does the same sort of survey, which YTD tracks the MBA survey rate closely.  The Fannie Mae survey rate averages just under two tenths of a percent above the MBA survey rate with the standard deviation the difference of these two rates of .0875 YTD.  The correlation between these two rates is .96225 so the Fannie Mae survey rate is a very good predictor of the MBA survey rate.   The Fannie Mae rate bottom out in November of 2012 at 3.31 percent.   Therefore, the MBA survey rate probably bottomed out somewhere around 3.50 percent give or take one tenth of a percent near that same date. I would guess the lowest MBA survey rate for that period given the close relationship between the two rates was no less than 3.40 percent.   I found no data for mortgage rates during the great depression.    	What Can I Conclude About the Base rate? I conclude the baseline or outside view of the floor of the MBA survey rate is about 3.40 percent.  Specifically, an MBA survey rate of 3.00 percent is probably .40 percent lower than the lowest it has been in the last half century.  WHAT IS THE INSIDE VIEW 	The federal reserve has purchased about $350 billion in mortgage backed securities in the last few months.  This is less than the 500 billion of mortgages purchased in the Great Recession but that occurred over three years.   	Also there is the comment of lapp0 who works in real estate.  He stated that banks are raising interest rates right now.   This was borne out in the above statistics for the last 60 days.  This makes sense because banks will want a higher return and borrowers with higher credit scores right now, given the risks mentioned above.  This did not occur to me when I did my initial forecast. However, it provides a strong logical basis for the notion that the MBA survey rate has a floor.  	The banks have no doubt priced into their current mortgage rates through June 27, 2020,  the falling GDP, deflation, and rising unemployment rates we will likely see in the next year.   	All in all, this is the most unusual economy in our nation’s history, but I think we are at—or very close to – the floor on the MBA survey rates.  I expect there is less than 10 percent chance the MBA survey rate will fall below 3.30 percent and a less than 1 percent chance this rate will fall below 3.25 percent—no  matter how far deflation or 30 year treasury rates fall. Even if bond yields continue to fall under these uncertain economic conditions, increasing lending risk may keep 30-year mortgages above 3.00% for the duration of this question. On the other hand, the Federal reserve has announced a policy to buy mortgage-backed securities in "vast amounts", [1] which may counteract the increasing risk in the mortgage market. The biggest factor in this prediction is the trend between the 30 year treasury rate and the 30 year mortgage rate[4]. As of March 29th, $251B of mortgage-backed securities had been purchased by the federal reserve, with the intent of lowering mortgage rates, which was successful. However, the mortgage industry is pushing back because counter-intuitively these purchases are hurting lenders, increasing volatility, and causing margin calls. “Margin calls on mortgage lenders reached staggering and unprecedented levels by the end of the week. For a significant number of lenders, many of which are well-capitalized, these margin calls are eroding their working capital and threatening their ability to continue to operate.”[3] The fed has been reducing their purchases of mortgage-backed securities in response. We are seeing mortgage credit crunch, similar to what we saw in '08. This is likely not on the same level, but it will result in upward pressure for in mortgage rates.[2] JP Morgan has stopped accepting HELOC applications during the crisis, and raised its mortgage lending standard. This will have two impacts: proportionally more loans will be given to higher credit rated households (a downward pressure for interest rates), and fewer mortgage loans will be given over all (an upward pressure for interest rates)[8]. JP Morgan is bracing for serious mortgage default risk [9]. The federal reserve likely will be able to stabilize the mortgage market, and continuing to purchase mortgage-backed securities to stimulate the economy. With interest rates already extremely low, mortage rates will not move significantly downwards unless an *extremely* large quantity of MBS are purchased by the Fed, among other actions. Jumping in very late on this one, but I’m very confused by how high the crowd is on this, and baffled as to whether there was EVER (within the duration of this question) a strong signal that rate would fall below 3.00%.

Regression on 10yr constant maturity on 30 year mortgage rates is holding steady. Beats have increased slightly since the Fed stepped in, but I think structural issues such as supply will keep a floor on rates until July. The quadratic model that better captures the relationship between the 10 year and mortgages in past crises is also holding up. Actuals are still coming in above the regression’s estimate.  Some downside risks remain given market volatility and presumable efforts by banks to ramp up refinancing staffs to address the supply gap. That being said, the MBA rate is consistently above the 30-year rate quoted on FRED (y-variable in my regression) so that provides some extra cushion. Cutting my forecast by a third.

The weekly MBA Report says "The average contract interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances ($510,400 or less) decreased to 3.41 percent from 3.43 percent, ..."  It could still happen, but the clock is ticking.  At this rate it won't reach 3.0% for several months.  Of course it could change very quickly too.

Even if bond yields continue to fall under these uncertain economic conditions, increasing lending risk may keep 30-year mortgages above 3.00% for the duration of this question. On the other hand, the Federal reserve has announced a policy to buy mortgage-backed securities in "vast amounts", [1] which may counteract the increasing risk in the mortgage market. The biggest factor in this prediction is the trend between the 30 year treasury rate and the 30 year mortgage rate[4]. As of March 29th, $251B of mortgage-backed securities had been purchased by the federal reserve, with the intent of lowering mortgage rates, which was successful. However, the mortgage industry is pushing back because counter-intuitively these purchases are hurting lenders, increasing volatility, and causing margin calls. “Margin calls on mortgage lenders reached staggering and unprecedented levels by the end of the week. For a significant number of lenders, many of which are well-capitalized, these margin calls are eroding their working capital and threatening their ability to continue to operate.”[3] The fed has been reducing their purchases of mortgage-backed securities in response. We are seeing mortgage credit crunch, similar to what we saw in '08. This is likely not on the same level, but it will result in upward pressure for in mortgage rates.[2] JP Morgan has stopped accepting HELOC applications during the crisis, and raised its mortgage lending standard. This will have two impacts: proportionally more loans will be given to higher credit rated households (a downward pressure for interest rates), and fewer mortgage loans will be given over all (an upward pressure for interest rates)[8]. JP Morgan is bracing for serious mortgage default risk [9]. The federal reserve likely will be able to stabilize the mortgage market, and continuing to purchase mortgage-backed securities to stimulate the economy, presenting a reasonable probability mortgage rates drop below 3%. The Financial Times article referenced below explains why the mortgage market has not been responding to the extremely low US Treasury rates.  According to the MBA, 7.54% of loans are now in forbearance.  Why would a loan originator take on 1000 new loans when chances are 75 of them will not make payments.  Until the loan can be packaged and sold to Fannie Mae or another investor the originator is responsible for payments of principal, interest, taxes, and insurance.  It's not an attractive proposition. I'm not a banker or a finance guy, so I really don't know what will happen.  But it seems that this question comes down to whether or not, and if so when, the government steps in to buy/guarantee mortgages that are in forbearance.  For now I will stay with the bet that the government will step in before the end of June.  But I will only go 5 points higher than the crowd, which is at 60%. https://www.mba.org/2020-press-releases/may/share-of-mortgage-loans-in-forbearance-increases-to-754 https://www.ft.com/content/a183170b-3920-4b74-b4be-641d35c7b256

mortgage rates have never gone that low. No matter how many mortgages the Fed buys, there has to be a floor in a rational world. Unless the Fed buys all of them. Inflation may fluctuate, might be below 2% short term and above 2% long term, but around 2% is what a lender/investor is likely thinking since that is the Fed target. At 3% mortgage that would only leave 1% for profit and risk compensation. And a rational investor would be thinking higher than normal risk right now. Last count we were still at 3.45%, even with Fed purchases. It's not coming down another 50 basis points. Although, I do think a lot of things are going to go crazy, like oil going negative. Weird things will happen in other markets too, but I don't expect this.

I think an environment of falling interest rates driven by the fed implies that rates would fall. while there will be massive fed efforts to boost the economy and pump liquidity into the money supply, and even though some of that is explicitly targeting mortgage rates, I don't think it will be enough to overcome:  1) they would need to fall a lot. A record amount to record lows. 
2) unemployment and dislocation will be high. The risk premium for foreclosure has to be up in this environment
3) there is a flight to quality and 30 year mortgages don't qualify in this environment because of #2 above. Treasury rates can go down while this is going up or staying flat as has been the case so far.

The Feds may continue pushing the interest rates down to offer cheap money as a stimulus. Large quantities of us may be jobless by May with no prospective re-employment opportunities, which translates to mass loan defaults and in turn leads to a negative market reaction that feeds the cycle by creating more layoffs. The solution is simple, but no one wants to see it.

I changed my mind on this. It has historically never been below 3.29%. CPI inflation is around 2.15%, and likely to rise with all the money printing and shortage of goods. The inflation rate sets a floor on the mortgage rate. Mortgage rates will never drop below inflation plus a certain risk & profit premium. Also all the rush of refinances are pushing rates up. The Fed dropped the Fed funds rate and mortgage rates actually went up due to demand.

I was wrong, and reconsidered my thinking.  It is clear that bond rates, which are the underpinning for the cost of funds for mortgages will be historically low.   However, that is not critical factor.  First - the number of people needing cash is going to boom.   The number of people applying for mortgages to fund their lifestyles while the epidemic rages is going through the roof.   So demand has surged.  Ability to service the loans has remained relatively constant.  So the ability to process loans is the bottleneck.  Increased demand with the same supply is a recipe for higher prices.  And with the cost of money low - this will be a good investment area.  All of this could reverse, at any time.   And I probably shouldn't be forecasting.   But since I had jumped in and made a mistake, I now have no option but to try to correct the mistake.  I don't think the need for cash abates before Jun 27.

I am updating my original forecast due to the Federal Reserve's move to purchase an additional $200 Billion in mortgage-backed securities over the next few months[1]. Since the Federal Reserve chair has stated that he doesn't think negative rates are appropriate for the US right now [2], that leaves the Federal reserve with limited tools to combat a future recession. This means it is possible that the Federal Reserve will increase its Quantitative Easing (QE) through additional purchases of mortgage-backed securities. However, this still leaves the issue of lending institutions not having the manpower available to process loans in a timely manner. Lenders could also be adversely impacted by the spread of COVID-19  and the CDC's recommendation of canceling gatherings of more than 50 people [3]. Further, the current glut of re-finance applications has created a possible loss of interest income for lenders that were not anticipated [4]. Ultimately, it will depend on the level of demand from individuals interested in refinancing their loans, the impact of COVID-19 on the workforce, and increased QE measures by the Federal Reserve. Thus, I am revising my original probability from a 12% to a 15% probability of 30-year fixed-rate mortgages with conforming loan balances in the U.S. falling below 3.00% by 27 June 2020. Please point out/correct any incorrect statements/analysis/assessments I have made. I really wish I could show charts in the rationale section here... I have been doing some research on this question over the past couple days and found the following:
1. obviously rates are falling due to global growth concerns based on the impact of the coronavirus
2. 30 year fixed rate mortgages are highly correlated (98% r-squared since 1990) with the yield on the 10 year Treasury
3. The Fed's recently announced bond purchases (https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-to-purchase-treasury-securities-to-address-market-disruptions-11584109975), along with investor demand, should keep rates low for the near future but expect the short-end to fall more than the long-end (steepening)
4. Lower rates make mortgage refinancing more attractive (https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/mortgage-applications)
5. This is putting a lot of stress on limited refinancing capacity (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/09/mortgage-rates-could-be-lower-but-lenders-struggling-to-keep-up-with-demand.html)  Now all of this begs the question of how low can mortgage rates go? Some reference European countries with negative govt bond and (in some cases) negative mortgage rates (https://themortgagereports.com/54915/no-floor-for-mortgage-rates-how-low-rates-could-actually-go). While a concern, I don't think rates are likely to go negative in the US given bank repo and money market functions in the US, negative rates would create more immediate problems than in Europe. On the other hand, the above-referenced article makes a fair point that mortgages have been breaking floors for the past couple years. This is where the charts come in. As I mentioned above to looking at the relationship between 30 year fixed mortgages and the 10 year (weekly data, end of period for the 10 year) since 1990 the relationship is linear and very strong. However, if I just isolate data points since Jan 2019 the linear relationship is still strong (81% r-squared) but there is strong serial correlation and a visual examination suggests that a quadratic equation would fit the data better (it does - higher r-squared and better t-stats). The quadratic suggests that as 10 year rates fall, mortgage rates fall at a slower rate. This indicates that a floor could be forming around 3.25%. To further validate, I looked at just data-points since the coronavirus started impacting the bond markets (mid-January) and the beta of my linear regression is significantly lower than the beta for the other two time-frames (since 1990 and since 2019). I think that this is largely due to low capacity to process refinancing applications and making sure banks can maintain profitability given the negative impact of low rates on their operations. IMPORTANT DISCLOSURE: This analysis is based on the Avg 30-year Fixed Rate US mortgage from Freddie Mac (not the MBA) since I couldn't find a free MBA time series to download. Visual examination shows the two are HIGHLY correlated and I couldn't find an reason why they shouldn't be. Data is available from the St. Louis Fed's FRED database (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MORTGAGE30US#0) the two series I used are MORTGAGE30US and DGS10.

During the great recession, the Fed benchmark rate was held at 0% between 2008 and 2015. The lowest the average 30-year Fixed-rate reached during that timeframe was 3.35% in November and December of 2012[1]. During that same timeframe, the 10-year Treasury Yield reached 1.626% and 1.742% respectively[2]. During the month of November, in 2012, Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac reported that there were 573,153 refinances processed. For the month of December, they reported 359,205 mortgages refinanced[3]. Also, during this time period banks were completing refinance applications in about 57 days [4]. Currently, the 10-year treasury rate has hit an all-time low in the past 7-10 days and the 30-year fixed mortgage rate reached an average of 3.47 for the month of February 2020. Further, the market is predicting a 95.6% possibility that the Fed will slash its benchmark lending rates to 0 during their 17-18 March meeting [5].  However, the 10-year treasury has gone back up to almost 1% and mortgage lenders have increased their rates by 1-3 points in the past 3-5 days. Further, some current lenders are allowing applicants to lock in rates for 100 days and many lending institutions do not have the staff to process the current workload due to staff cuts between 2018-2019 [6]. Thus, major lending institutions are actively keeping rates high to dissuade more individuals from re-financing because they cannot process the applications. Further, these processing delays could be exacerbated as school closures and travel restrictions increase. If any of the major lenders shuts down their offices, it will increase the processing timeline. With rate locks extending at least 100 days and lenders not having the manpower to process applications in a timely manner, it seems unlikely that mortgage rates would fall below the 3% limit, especially since that limit has never been reached. If banks are able to hire more mortgage processors/loan officers, AND, the federal government promises to provide additional financial backing for mortgage securities, the rate could drop below 3%, but both of those scenarios seem unlikely to cause a decrease to below 3% by 27 Jun, especially since rates are currently averaging between 3.75-4%.
